contextId.information: A decision that will not be changed is spoken of as something firm. AT: "you see that I will not change my decision about this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you see how firm my decision is about this

contextId.information: Nebuchadnezzar's anger and rage were so intense that they are spoken of as if they had filled him up. Here "anger" and "rage" mean about the same thing and are used to emphasize how upset the king was. AT: "extremely angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: filled with anger and rage

contextId.information: The king was so angry that rage is spoken of as if it were filling him up. AT: "Nebuchadnezzar became extremely angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Nebuchadnezzar was filled with rage

contextId.information: Not obeying the king's command is spoken of as if they had physically moved it away from them. AT: "they ignored my command" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they set aside my command

contextId.information: To rebel against God is spoken of as raising oneself up against him. AT: "You have rebelled against the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You have lifted yourself up against the Lord

contextId.information: Judging the worthiness of the king to rule is spoken of as weighing him. This means that the king is not worthy to rule. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has examined your worthiness to rule, and he has found that you are not worthy"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: you are weighed in the scales and are found lacking

contextId.information: This does not mean the fourth kingdom will destroy the planet, but that it will brutally attack, conquer, and destroy all other kingdoms on earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: It will devour ... it into pieces

contextId.information: The horn ignoring truth and godliness is spoken of as if it will throw truth to the ground. AT: "The horn will reject the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The horn will throw truth down to the ground

contextId.information: The angel speaks about the vision as if it were a scroll that could be closed with a wax seal. This prevented anyone from seeing the contents until the seal was broken. AT: "close and seal up what you have written about the vision" or "do not tell anyone about the vision now" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: seal up the vision

contextId.information: Being righteous is spoken of as if "righteousness" were an object that belongs to Yahweh. The abstract noun "righteousness" can be stated as an action. AT: "Lord, you act justly" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: To you, Lord, belongs righteousness

contextId.information: Having these traits is spoken of as if they belonged to the Lord. AT: "The Lord our God is compassionate and forgives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: To the Lord our God belong compassion and forgiveness

contextId.information: The abundance of the curse and the oath are spoken of as if they were poured out like water. This can be stated in active form. AT: "you have brought upon us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: have been poured out on us

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably as if Yahweh's face shone a light. AT: "act kindly toward" (UDB) or "act with favor toward" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: make your face shine on

contextId.information: The army will destroy the city and the holy place just as a flood destroys things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Its end will come with a flood

contextId.information: The idea of rising up or standing is often used for someone who becomes powerful. AT: "A mighty king will begin to reign" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A mighty king will rise up

contextId.information: Here "arm" stands for power. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: her arm's strength ... his arm

contextId.information: This family is spoken of as if it were a tree. The roots represent ancestors, and the branch represents a  descendant. AT: "a descendant of her ancestors" or "one of her descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a branch from her roots

contextId.information: Being lifted up represents the idea of becoming very proud. AT: "will become very proud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will be lifted up

contextId.information: Here the idea of rising up represents rebelling. AT: "many people will rebel against the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: many will rise against the king

contextId.information: Here stumbling represents failing. AT: "they will not succeed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they will stumble

contextId.information: Not standing represents being defeated. AT: "the king of the South will be defeated" or "his army will be defeated"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he will not stand

contextId.information: Here the severe defeat of an army is spoken of as a flood of water that completely sweeps it away. AT: "The enemy will completely defeat his army" or "His enemy will completely destroy his army as a flood destroys everything in its path" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: His army will be swept away like a flood

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents a person's desires. Desires are spoken of here as if they were an object that someone could set or place in a certain position. AT: "each determined to do evil to the other" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with their hearts set on evil against each other

contextId.information: Taking away the offering represents preventing people from offering it. AT: "They will stop the priests from presenting the regular burnt offering"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They will take away the regular burnt offering

contextId.information: Here "stumble" is a metaphor that represents experiencing a disaster of one kind or another, including death itself. Here "sword" represents battles and warfare, and "flame" represents fire. AT: "they will die in battle and by burning to death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they will stumble by the sword and by flame

contextId.information: Here "stumble" is a metaphor that represents experiencing a disaster of one kind or another, including death itself. The phrase "being robbed" can be stated in active form. AT: "they will become slaves and their enemies will rob them of their possessions for days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: they will stumble into captivity and into being robbed for days

contextId.information: Here "join themselves" represents "come to help." AT: "will come to help them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will join themselves

contextId.information: Here "stumble" represents experiencing a disaster of one kind or another, including death itself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Some of the wise will stumble

contextId.information: This refers to making people, places, or objects suitable for God's use by separating them from sin and other forms of evil. It speaks of evil as if it were physical dirtiness that could be removed by washing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cleansing

contextId.information: Here this represents pretending to be very important and powerful. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: make himself great

contextId.information: This phrase pictures God as storing up his wrath until his storeroom is completely full of it and he is ready to act according to it. AT: "until God is completely angry with him" or "until God is angry enough to take action against him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: until the wrath is completed

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents power and control. AT: "He will extend his control over various lands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will extend his hand into lands

contextId.information: This refers to those who help others understand that they are separated from God, as if they were changing the direction in which they were going. AT: "those who teach others to live righteously" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: those who turn many to righteousness

contextId.information: The vision that was given to Daniel was not to be explained. The book was sealed and no one could access it. AT: "for you are to close up and seal the words you have written" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for the words are shut up and sealed
